unnormalised: **Air Quality Deterioration Raises Concerns Ahead of Diwali**
normalised: Air Quality Deterioration Raises Concerns Ahead of Diwali

unnormalised: New Delhi – Air quality across major Indian cities, particularly in the Indo-Gangetic Plain, has shown a marked decline, raising concerns among environmental watchdogs ahead of the Diwali festival. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) reported an average Air Quality Index (AQI) of 185 in Delhi, categorized as “moderate,” with some areas exceeding 250, reaching "poor" levels.
normalised: New Delhi – Air quality across major Indian cities, particularly in the Indo-Gangetic Plain, has shown a marked decline, raising concerns among environmental watchdogs ahead of the Diwali festival. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) reported an average Air Quality Index (A Q I) of one hundred and eighty five in Delhi, categorized as “moderate,” with some areas exceeding two hundred and fifty, reaching "poor" levels.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the deterioration to a combination of factors including vehicular emissions, industrial activity, and stubble burning in neighboring states like Punjab and Haryana. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecasts stagnant air conditions, potentially exacerbating the situation.
normalised: Experts attribute the deterioration to a combination of factors including vehicular emissions, industrial activity, and stubble burning in neighboring states like Punjab and Haryana. The India Meteorological Department (I M D) forecasts stagnant air conditions, potentially exacerbating the situation.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma, Head of the Environmental Sciences Department at IIT Kanpur, urged citizens to adopt eco-friendly practices during Diwali celebrations to mitigate the adverse impact. "Switching to green crackers and limiting firework displays can significantly improve air quality," he stated. Concerns are also mounting for vulnerable populations, particularly children and the elderly, who are more susceptible to respiratory ailments. The sale of air purifiers has reportedly seen a spike, mirroring trends observed during the festive season in recent years. The CPCB has also launched a public awareness campaign advising citizens to avoid prolonged outdoor activities when the AQI is poor. The agency hopes to reduce the levels of PM2.5 and PM10 particles in the air by promoting sustainable Diwali celebrations.
